wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant General Sir Rufane Shaw Donkin  (1772 – 1 May 1841), known to close friends and family as ‘Donks’, was a British army officer of the Napoleonic era and later Member of Parliament.

link_mentions.page: List of places named after people
response: * Port Elizabeth – Elizabeth Donkin (wife of acting governor Sir Rufane Shaw Donkin)
*Rufane Shaw Donkin (1773–1841), founder of Port Elizabeth
* 1 May - Sir Rufane Shaw Donkin, acting Governor of the Cape Colony who supervised the arrival and settling of the British settlers and who founded Port Elizabeth, dies in Southampton, England

In 1820, the rising seaport of Algoa Bay was named "Port Elizabeth" in memory of Elizabeth Frances née Markham, the late wife of Rufane Shaw Donkin, acting Governor of the Cape Colony. Colonists also called the settlement "The Bay". The settlement is also known as "iBhayi" or "eBhayi", a Xhosa adaptation of the Afrikaans name "die Baai" meaning "the bay", by Xhosa speakers.

In 1820, a party of 4,000 British settlers arrived by sea, encouraged by the government of the Cape Colony to form a settlement to strengthen the border region between the Cape Colony and the Xhosa people. At this time the seaport town was founded by Sir Rufane Shaw Donkin, the Acting Governor of the Cape Colony (in office: 1820–1821).
*Rufane Shaw Donkin military hero who committed suicide
*1837–1841: Gen Sir Rufane Shaw Donkin KCB GCH
